landmarks.name: Square One Brewery & Distillery
amenities: Outdoor courtyard patio with waterfalls and ponds

history.event: Christopher Schumacher builds the corner tavern at 18th Street and Park Avenue, serving the Lafayette Square neighborhood.
Anheuser-Busch acquires the building, operating it as a "Tied House" with a tavern and dance hall serving exclusively A-B products.
Operated as a soda fountain during Prohibition.

Bob Cassilly (future creator of City Museum) purchases the building and installs salvaged architectural elements: wooden columns from a demolished church, a fountain from a house razed for the Interstate, and a skylight from Alexian Brothers Hospital.
Major fire damages the building. Owner Steve Neukomm undertakes a significant renovation of the structure and courtyard.
Square One Brewery & Distillery opens in February, founded by Steve Neukomm as a neighborhood brewpub.
Becomes Missouri's first licensed micro-distillery since Prohibition, launching the Spirits of St. Louis line of whiskey, gin, vodka, rum, and agave spirits.

landmarks.description: A neighborhood brewery, distillery, and gastropub in a storied 1882 corner building on Park Avenue. Owner Steve Neukomm brews 35+ styles annually and distills the Spirits of St. Louis line — Missouri's first micro-distillery since Prohibition. The courtyard patio is widely considered one of the best in St. Louis.

landmarks.name: Park Avenue Coffee
amenities: Indoor seating in historic bank vault

history.event: Building constructed in Second Empire Victorian style during Lafayette Square's peak development period, featuring mansard roof and limestone facade.
Lafayette Square becomes a designated City historic district, preserving the building's architectural heritage.
Lafayette Square Historic District entered into the National Register of Historic Places.
Park Avenue Coffee opens at 1919 Park Ave as a neighborhood coffee shop specializing in locally roasted coffee and St. Louis gooey butter cake.
Ann & Allen Baking Company established to produce Park Avenue Coffee's signature gooey butter cakes, growing to 75 different flavors.
Park Avenue Coffee launches its own coffee roasting operations, air-roasting small batches in the most eco-friendly facility in the Midwest.

landmarks.name: Extra Wavy
amenities: Raw bar with 5-6 rotating oyster selections
Full bar with craft cocktails and martini program
Historic cellar event space (Malt House Cellar)

history.event: Centennial Malt House built by Joseph Schnaider as part of his Chouteau Avenue Brewery complex. Designed by Fred W. Wolf (Chicago engineer) and Louis Kledus (St. Louis architect).
Schnaider's brewery merged with St. Louis Brewing Association, becoming one of the top three local breweries.
Wendy and Paul Hamilton purchase the building and complete a $4 million restoration, opening Vin de Set restaurant in 2006.
Fire in September causes extensive damage, forcing closure of Vin de Set, PW Pizza, and 21st Street Brewer's Bar.
Malt House Lofts LLC purchases the building and begins mixed-use renovation including restaurant space and residential lofts.
Extra Wavy opens October 15 by On Point Hospitality (Travis Howard and Tim Wiggins), bringing modern American seafood and raw bar to Lafayette Square.
Building constructed on S Jefferson Avenue as a Depression-era commercial storefront near Lafayette Square.
St. Louis' original Chinatown (Hop Alley) demolished for Busch Stadium, dispersing Chinese restaurant owners into surrounding neighborhoods.
Chop suey restaurants establish a stronghold in St. Louis working-class neighborhoods, one of only three American cities where the cuisine thrives.
Jefferson Chop Suey continues traditional Chinese-American chop suey cuisine, serving the south city community with a loyal neighborhood following.
Jefferson Chop Suey remains a working neighborhood institution, preserving St. Louis' unique chop suey culture with cash-only operations and classic Cantonese-American dishes.

landmarks.name: Master G's Styling Studio
landmarks.description: Neighborhood hair salon specializing in natural hair care with unique and fun styles for every occasion. Services include blowouts, sew-in weaves, braids, retwists, relaxer & style, press & curl, and protective styling. Book via Booksy.
amenities: Sew-in weaves and quick weave installations
Custom braid styles and protective styling

landmarks.name: Frontenac Cleaners West End
landmarks.description: Neighborhood dry cleaner established in 1950, one of the longest-running businesses in Lafayette Square. Full-service garment care including dry cleaning, alterations, shirt laundering, shoe and leather repair, and drapery cleaning. Pick-up and delivery available. Now under new ownership.

history.event: Frontenac Cleaners established, operating from Park Avenue in Lafayette Square.
Lafayette Square designated a historic district, one of St. Louis's first protected neighborhoods. Frontenac Cleaners continues as a neighborhood anchor.

landmarks.name: Polite Society

history.event: Building constructed as three vintage storefronts facing Lafayette Park, within what would become the city's first historic district.
Ricardo's Italian Cafe opens and becomes a beloved neighborhood landmark, operating for 26 years.
Ricardo's closes after a quarter century. The space sits vacant.
Brian Schmitz and Jonathan Schoen begin a year-long renovation, paying homage to the neighborhood's Victorian roots.
Polite Society opens with Chef Thomas Futrell. The name nods to Lafayette Square's genteel 19th-century character.
The Drawing Room opens on the second floor — a 2,000 sq ft private event space with its own kitchen, bar, and a hidden speakeasy-style entrance behind a bookcase.

landmarks.description: A restaurant, bar & gathering place in the heart of Lafayette Square. Eclectic contemporary American fare with a celebrated weekend brunch. Owned by Brian Schmitz and Jonathan Schoen, with Executive Chef Eliott Harris at the helm.

landmarks.name: Baileys' Chocolate Bar
amenities: Full bar with 90+ beers and wines

history.event: Victorian townhouse constructed during Lafayette Square's golden age, in the Second Empire style typical of Park Avenue's fashionable residential mansions.
Building becomes part of Lafayette Square City Historic District, one of St. Louis's first protected neighborhoods.
Property included in Lafayette Square's entry into the National Register of Historic Places.
Dave and Kara Bailey open Bailey's Chocolate Bar as St. Louis's original dessert and martini bar, transforming the historic townhouse into an intimate dining destination.
Bailey's Chocolate Bar celebrates its 20th anniversary, marking two decades as a Lafayette Square landmark and romantic dining destination.

landmarks.name: 33 Wine Shop & Bar
landmarks.description: Beloved neighborhood wine bar celebrating 25 years in Lafayette Square. 500+ curated wines, craft beers, and cocktails with an 85-page list. Free tastings every Tuesday. Spacious patio reminiscent of a New Orleans courtyard.
amenities: 500+ curated wines from around the world
Retail wine shop with to-go pricing ($15 corkage)
Free wine tastings every Tuesday 5:30-7:30 PM
Cheese and charcuterie boards (Volpi, Salume Beddu)
Food by Khana (butter chicken flatbread, Brussels sprouts)

history.event: Victorian commercial building constructed on Park Avenue during Lafayette Square's golden age.
Jake Hafner (later of Civil Life Brewing Co.) opens 33 Wine Shop & Bar, bringing a curated wine experience to Lafayette Square.
Sommeliers James Smallwood and Jessica Spitzer purchase the bar — the second time it was sold to a loyal customer.
Expands food program with Khana chefs Nhat Nguyen and Remy Javed, adding butter chicken flatbread and shareable plates.
Celebrates 25 years as a Lafayette Square institution.

landmarks.name: Acosta Hair Design
landmarks.description: Boutique hair salon founded in 2017 by Josie Acosta, who trained at one of the Top 200 Salons in North America (Bobby Cooper Salon, Indianapolis) and with top technicians in New York and Chicago. Specializes in color, cutting, extensions, and Brazilian blowouts. Nextdoor Neighborhood Favorite 2018 and 2019.

history.event: Josie and Israel Acosta move from Indianapolis to St. Louis and open Acosta Hair Design at 1901 Park Avenue in Lafayette Square.
Named a Nextdoor Neighborhood Favorite by residents of the Lafayette Square area.
Receives Nextdoor Neighborhood Favorite award for a second consecutive year.

landmarks.name: Vicini Pastaria
landmarks.description: Handmade fresh pasta shop, café, and Italian market by chef Dawn Wilson, a molecular geneticist turned pasta artisan who trained in Tuscany. Best New Restaurant 2023 (Feast Magazine). Signature pici cacio e pepe.
amenities: Handmade fresh pasta sold by the pound
Italian specialty market and imported goods

history.event: Victorian commercial building constructed on Park Avenue during Lafayette Square's development.
Chef Dawn Wilson, a St. Louis native and former molecular genetics researcher, launches the original Vicini in Chicago after training in Tuscany.
Wilson returns to St. Louis and opens Vicini Pastaria, Café & Market at 1916 Park Avenue in November, bringing handmade fresh pasta to Lafayette Square.
Named Best New Restaurant by Feast Magazine's Feast 50 Readers' Choice Awards and Best Italian Restaurant by Riverfront Times.

landmarks.name: Chad M. Lawson Fine Art
landmarks.description: Contemporary art studio of Chad M. Lawson, known for striking abstract paintings on salvaged wooden doors. His layered, gestural work in oil and acrylic incorporates the wood's imperfections, with recurring sankofa symbols representing wisdom in learning from the past.
amenities: Abstract paintings on salvaged wooden doors

history.event: Victorian townhouse constructed on Park Avenue during Lafayette Square's peak development, part of the neighborhood's finest residential row.
Building becomes part of Lafayette Square Historic District, one of St. Louis's first protected neighborhoods and the city's oldest historic district.
Chad M. Lawson establishes his fine art studio in the building, bringing contemporary abstract art to Lafayette Square's historic Park Avenue corridor.

landmarks.name: Grow Hair Co
landmarks.description: Suite-style salon collective where independent beauty professionals collaborate. Services include hair coloring, cutting, styling, extensions, balayage, HydraFacials, brow lamination, and airbrush spray tans.

landmarks.name: Nu-Look Cleaners
landmarks.description: Family-owned dry cleaner and self-service laundromat operating in Lafayette Square since 1984. A+ BBB rating with zero complaints over 41 years. Full-service dry cleaning, alterations, leather cleaning, and coin-operated washers and dryers.

history.event: Nu-Look Cleaners Inc. founded by Steven Krekorian on Park Avenue in Lafayette Square, offering dry cleaning and self-service laundry.
Better Business Bureau opens file on the business, which maintains zero complaints and an A+ rating throughout its history.

landmarks.name: Winnie's Wine Bar
amenities: 30+ wines by the glass with Coravin system
Shareable small plates from Hamilton's kitchen

history.event: Building constructed as a machine shop for trucks in Lafayette Square's industrial corridor along Chouteau Avenue.
Paul Hamilton purchases the building at 2101 Chouteau Avenue and begins Hamilton Hospitality's transformation of the Chouteau corridor.
Charleville Brewing Company opens in a portion of the renovated space.

Winnie's Wine Bar opens in the former Charleville space, named after Wendy Hamilton's childhood nickname. Designed with retro aviation theme featuring 3-D world map, vintage propellers, and suitcase tables.

landmarks.name: Malt House Lofts
landmarks.description: Historic 1876 brewery malt house, now a mixed-use landmark with loft apartments, event venues, and ground-floor restaurants including Extra Wavy and Prohibition speakeasy.

history.event: Centennial Malt House built by Joseph Schnaider as part of his Chouteau Avenue Brewery, named to commemorate the U.S. Centennial. Designed by Fred W. Wolf (Chicago) and Louis Kledus (St. Louis).
Joseph Schnaider dies, leaving wife Elizabeth a prosperous brewery with a nationally-known open-air beer garden — one of St. Louis's most successful entertainment venues.
Schnaider's brewery merges with St. Louis Brewing Association, ranking among the top three local breweries.
Paul and Wendy Hamilton purchase the long-vacant malt house and begin a $4 million restoration.
Vin de Set restaurant opens — St. Louis's first rooftop restaurant with 4,000 sq ft rooftop patio. Named to Landmarks Association's 'Eleven Most Enhanced Places.'
Major fire in September damages the building, permanently closing all Hamilton Hospitality venues (Vin de Set, PW Pizza, 21st Street Brewer's Bar).
Malt House Lofts LLC (Rich Conyers / BOTI Architecture) purchases property for $2.2M and announces $2M renovation: 17 loft apartments, restaurant space, and event venues.
Extra Wavy opens October 15 on the ground floor. Prohibition speakeasy opens in the cellar. Loft construction continues on upper floors.

landmarks.name: SqWires Restaurant & Market
amenities: Weekend brunch with DIY Bloody Mary & Mimosa bar
Outdoor patio overlooking Park Avenue Plaza Fountain
Private dining (The Annex, up to 150 guests)

history.event: Building constructed as the American Bed Factory, a large industrial complex spanning a full city block in Lafayette Square.
Western Wire Products Company purchases 35,000 sq ft of the building and begins wire manufacturing operations.
Western Wire vacates after 66 years, relocating to Fenton, Missouri. The building sits empty.

Tom Cohen (Cohen Architecture) and Parkside Development begin a $12 million renovation into Wireworks Lofts and restaurant space, financed with Historic Tax Credits. During construction, one building catches fire; the burned-out shell is converted into an enclosed courtyard.
SqWires Restaurant & Market opens, founded by Bethany Budde. The name is a portmanteau of "Square" (Lafayette Square) and "Wires" (the wire factory). Bethany later marries architect Tom Cohen.
Receives Earth Day 365 Sustainability Award. Over two decades as a women-owned neighborhood anchor.

landmarks.description: A Lafayette Square anchor since 2001, set inside a beautifully converted 1900s wire factory. Chef-owner Bethany Budde-Cohen serves seasonal New American fare with trademark simplicity and richness of flavor. The urban market and weekend brunch are neighborhood institutions.

landmarks.name: Eleven Eleven Mississippi
amenities: Seasonal farm-to-table menu from on-site greenhouse
Oak-fired brick oven in open display kitchen
Glass-enclosed wine cellar private dining (8-12 guests)

history.event: Building constructed as part of the Roberts, Johnson and Rand shoe manufacturing complex in Lafayette Square.
Roberts, Johnson and Rand contracted architect Theodore Link (designer of Union Station) to expand operations. The factory complex measured 60 feet wide, 350 feet long, and 5 stories tall.
RJ&R merged with Peters Shoe Company to form the International Shoe Company, the largest shoe manufacturer in the United States.
Lafayette Square designated as St. Louis's oldest historic district, placed on the National Register of Historic Places.
Paul and Wendy Hamilton purchased the dilapidated 100-year-old warehouse and opened Eleven Eleven Mississippi in December, serving award-winning Tuscan/Californian cuisine.
Paul and Wendy Hamilton named Restaurateurs of the Year by the Missouri Restaurant Association.
Restaurant celebrates 20 years of farm-to-table cuisine with ingredients from their on-site commercial hydroponic greenhouse, The Towers urban farm.

landmarks.name: Saint Joseph's Church
landmarks.description: Former Church of the Unity (Unitarian, 1869) turned St. Joseph Lithuanian Catholic Church (1916–1970). A small stone Gothic Revival chapel at the corner of Park Avenue and MacKay Place, with stained glass windows and attached rectory. Closed since 1970 when the Lithuanian community moved out of the neighborhood.

history.event: Built as the Church of the Unity, a Unitarian chapel, for $8,000. Founded with assistance from Rev. William Greenleaf Eliot and the Church of the Messiah.
One-story addition constructed for $4,000, expanding the chapel's capacity.
The Great Cyclone of May 27 tears the roof off the church. Rebuilt in the following months.
Lithuanian Catholic community acquires the building, renaming it St. Joseph Lithuanian Catholic Church. Serves immigrants who had previously attended St. John Nepomuk.
Church closes as the Lithuanian community, now prosperous, moves out of Lafayette Square during the neighborhood's period of decline.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Park United Methodist Church
landmarks.description: Active Reconciling United Methodist congregation in a stunning Romanesque Revival limestone church with Gothic tower inspired by Notre Dame. Features a theater-style octagonal sanctuary with four balconies, colorful stained glass, cherry pews, and a restored 1901 Kilgen pipe organ.
amenities: Fellowship Hall and bowling alley (1950s basement)

history.event: Founded as Wesley Chapel Society, a small Methodist group meeting at the home of Elizabeth Carter.
Congregation relocates to 2300 Lafayette Avenue on Easter Sunday, marching from their previous Chouteau Avenue location. Adopts the name Lafayette Park Methodist Church.
The Great Cyclone of May 27 severely damages and unroofs the building. August Busch Sr., a member and choir singer, helps fund reconstruction.

New stone sanctuary fronting Lafayette Avenue completed, designed in Romanesque Revival style with a Gothic tower inspired by Notre Dame. Architect attributed to Theodore C. Link (designer of Union Station).
Kilgen pipe organ installed — a 2-manual, 14-rank instrument that remains in use today after professional restoration in 1999.
Church joins the Reconciling Ministries Network, formally welcoming all people regardless of age, gender, race, or sexual orientation.

landmarks.name: City Church
landmarks.description: Evangelical Presbyterian congregation meeting in the former Immaculate Conception Catholic Church rectory. The original Gothic Revival church complex (1908) was designed by Barnett, Haynes & Barnett, one of St. Louis's most prominent architectural firms. City Church's mission: 'Seeing the Gospel bring renewal to St. Louis.'

history.event: Immaculate Conception Parish founded as St. Kevin in Lafayette Square.
Gothic Revival church designed by Barnett, Haynes & Barnett (architects of the Cathedral Basilica of St. Louis) completed at Lafayette Avenue.
Classical Revival rectory completed adjacent to the church, featuring 13 bedrooms across two upper floors.
Immaculate Conception Catholic Parish closes; parishioners transfer to St. Margaret of Scotland.
City Church, an evangelical Presbyterian congregation, establishes itself in the former rectory building, bringing new life to the historic complex.

landmarks.name: Hamilton's Urban Steakhouse & Bourbon Bar
amenities: Signature bacon fat candle charcuterie board

history.event: Building constructed as a machine shop for trucks in Lafayette Square's industrial corridor along Chouteau Avenue.
Paul Hamilton purchases the former machine shop building at 2101 Chouteau Avenue.
Charleville Brewing Company & Tavern opens in the renovated space, featuring reclaimed wood and metal, preserving original pulleys and beams.
Hamilton's Urban Steakhouse & Bourbon Bar opens within the building. Paul Hamilton, Wendy Hamilton, and Jason Arnold officially partner on the venture.
Hamilton Hospitality installs 1,500 sq ft commercial hydroponic greenhouse with vertical aeroponic towers, growing 3,000+ plants for farm-to-table dining.

landmarks.name: Planter's House
amenities: Happy hour Tue-Fri 4-6pm, all day Sunday
The Bullock Room — hidden second bar behind velvet curtain

history.event: Original Planter's House Hotel opens on Second Street in downtown St. Louis, becoming a legendary gathering place for travelers, politicians, and businessmen.
Pivotal Civil War meeting at the Planter's Hotel: Union Col. Nathaniel Lyon tells Missouri Governor Claiborne Jackson 'This means war,' a moment that helped keep Missouri in the Union.
Original Planter's House Hotel closes after over a century of operation.
Ted Kilgore, Jamie Kilgore, and Ted Charak open the modern Planter's House on December 5 (Repeal Day), paying tribute to the historic hotel with an award-winning cocktail program.
Named James Beard Award semifinalist for Outstanding Bar Program, one of the highest honors in the American food and drink industry.

landmarks.name: Saint Mary's Assumption Catholic Church
landmarks.description: English Gothic Revival church built in 1871 as St. John's Episcopal Church, later serving Lithuanian and Ukrainian Catholic communities. Since 1997, home to a Society of St. Pius X (SSPX) traditionalist Catholic chapel offering the Latin Mass. Features a truncated Gothic tower, engaged buttresses, and a restored pipe organ.

history.event: Built as St. John's Episcopal Church. First service held Easter Sunday 1872 by Rev. J.P.T. Ingraham. Construction plagued by cost overruns from unexpected foundation problems.
Acquired by the Ruthenian Catholic community and renamed St. Mary's Assumption. First Liturgy celebrated on the Feast of the Assumption.
Purchased by the Metropolitan Community Church of Greater St. Louis, serving a congregation of approximately 130 members.
Building purchased and restored by the Society of St. Pius X (SSPX), who install a new pipe organ and establish a traditionalist Catholic chapel offering the Latin Mass.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Preparatory Academy
landmarks.description: Top-ranked public charter school (PK–8) in a renovated 1868 Baptist church complex. Ranked #1 among St. Louis City schools in reading, science, and math. Sponsored by UMSL, serving 400+ students with a 7:1 student-teacher ratio.
amenities: #1 in St. Louis City for reading, science, and math
Athletics: basketball, cheerleading, cross country, soccer, volleyball

history.event: Lafayette Baptist Church (originally Park Avenue Baptist Church) founded. The congregation eventually builds a church complex at the corner of Lafayette and Mississippi avenues.
Great Cyclone causes $8,000 in damage and partially collapses the school building. Both structures rebuilt the same year.
Peak membership of 1,300 with 1,400 Sunday School students. Additional classroom buildings constructed in the 1940s and 1960s.
Group of parents and community members secure a charter from UMSL to create Lafayette Preparatory Academy, supporting Lafayette Square's neighborhood revitalization.
School moves to its 'forever home' at 1900 Lafayette Avenue after a $2.1M renovation of the former Baptist church complex, converting Sunday School buildings into modern classrooms.
Middle school and gymnasium expansion completed. First 8th grade class graduates in May.
Ranked #1 among all St. Louis City schools in reading, science, and math on state MAP tests. Charter renewed for a 10-year term.

landmarks.name: Seib House
landmarks.description: Historic 1882 Romanesque Revival mansion, home to the Seib family for over 90 years. Carrie Seib ran the Independent Church of Truth from the third-floor ballroom (1933–1964), channeling poetry and spiritual messages. Beautifully restored in 2019.

history.event: Mansion built for a German-born steamboat captain during Lafayette Square's golden age, featuring a grand third-floor ballroom and 8,000 square feet of living space.
Carrie Seib, a German immigrant who made her fortune in the bakery business, purchases the mansion and moves in with her large extended family.

Carrie establishes the Independent Church of Truth, holding Sunday evening services in the third-floor ballroom. She performs clairvoyant readings, spiritual healing, and channels poetry from an entity she calls the 'Eastern Star.'
After 31 years of weekly services, the Independent Church of Truth holds its final gathering.
Carrie Seib dies. Daughter Edna (Washington University art graduate) becomes matriarch, maintaining the house with brother Dr. George Seib, a Washington University anatomy professor.

Artist Lew Blink discovers 13 boxes of Carrie's reel-to-reel sermon recordings in a dumpster outside the house, launching the 'Dumpster Archaeology' art project that brings renewed attention to Lafayette Square's spiritualist history.
New owners complete a major restoration, featured on the Lafayette Square house tour. The Seib family approves of the careful renovation.

landmarks.name: Rosé By Peno
amenities: Nitro wine system with 24 wines by the glass

history.event: Building constructed in Lafayette Square during the neighborhood's period of commercial development along 18th Street.
Lafayette Square declared a historic district by the City of Saint Louis.
Building served as Stray Rescue's 18th Street Shelter, a nonprofit animal rescue organization founded by Randy Grim.
Stray Rescue relocated to a larger downtown facility, leaving the 18th Street location vacant.
Chef Pepe Kehm opens Rosé by Peno on March 9, combining coastal French and Italian cuisine in an intimate 38-seat bistro with design by local artist Kevin Glazer.

landmarks.name: Rhone Rum Bar
amenities: Outdoor patio with operable garage door

history.event: Building at 2107 Chouteau Avenue constructed to house Champ Spring Company, a buggy spring manufacturer that would operate for over 100 years.
Rhone Rum Bar opens December 7, featuring 101+ rums and Caribbean-inspired cuisine. Named after the RMS Rhone, a legendary 1871 shipwreck in the British Virgin Islands.
Wins St. Louis Magazine's A-List award for Best Rum Selection. Transitions to private events only in October 2019.

landmarks.name: Save-A-Lot
landmarks.description: Discount grocery store anchoring the Jefferson Commons development. Opened in 2013 to address a federally designated food desert after the space sat vacant for nearly a decade. Recently remodeled with a $1M investment. Accepts EBT, WIC, and offers delivery via DoorDash and Instacart.
amenities: Full grocery including fresh produce and meat counter
Accepts EBT, WIC, and healthy benefits cards
Delivery via DoorDash, Instacart, and Uber Eats
Partners with Too Good To Go (surplus food bags $6.99)

history.event: Building constructed as a Kroger supermarket on South Jefferson Avenue.
Kroger exits St. Louis; store sold to National Supermarkets.
National chain goes out of business; store closes. Neighborhood classified as a USDA food desert.
Foodland, the last tenant, closes. Building sits vacant for nearly a decade.
Green Streets Development Group purchases the property. TIF Commission approves $1.7M in public funds. Save-A-Lot commits to lease the space as anchor of the new Jefferson Commons development.
Save-A-Lot opens in the 17,600 sq ft space, hiring 20-25 community residents and ending the neighborhood's food desert status.
Save-A-Lot exercises early lease renewal and invests approximately $1M in a full interior remodel.

landmarks.name: The Bellwether

history.event: Built as the Power Plant for the City Hospital complex, designed by architect Albert Osburg, funded by the Public Works Administration (PWA). Three-story red brick with tall ceilings and smokestack.
City Hospital operated on this site from 1845, one of the oldest public hospitals west of the Mississippi.
City Hospital closes in June after 140 years of operation. Power Plant building goes dormant.
Building adaptively reused; Climb So iLL rock climbing gym opens on the lower floors.
Element restaurant occupies the upper floor space, establishing the dining concept for the building.
The Bellwether opens May 31 in the former Element space on floors 2–3. Created by the Polite Society team: Brian Schmitz, Jonathan Schoen, and chef Thomas Futrell.

landmarks.description: A rooftop restaurant and cocktail bar by Be Polite Hospitality (Brian Schmitz & Jonathan Schoen) inside the 1937 City Hospital Power Plant. Executive Chef Thomas Futrell's seasonal American menu pairs with literary-themed cocktails named after novels. The Reference Room on the third floor offers private dining for up to 30 guests. Happy hour runs Tue–Fri 5–6 PM.

landmarks.name: Clementine's Naughty & Nice Creamery

history.event: Tamara Keefe opens the original Clementine's on South Grand, pioneering boozy ice cream in St. Louis with a patent-pending alcohol-freezing process.
Lafayette Square location opens at 1637 S 18th Street in an 1888 Second Empire building, quickly becoming a neighborhood destination.
Named by Buzzfeed and Yelp as the most popular ice cream shop in Missouri. MSN crowns it the best ice cream parlor in the state.
Expands to Clayton location near the zoo. Lafayette Square remains the flagship.

landmarks.description: St. Louis's first microcreamery, churning small-batch ice cream in "naughty" (boozy) and "nice" varieties. The gooey butter cake flavor is the #1 seller. Named Missouri's most popular ice cream shop by Buzzfeed and Yelp.

landmarks.name: Zumwalt Corporation

history.event: Maurice Richard Zumwalt, age 22, opens a company in St. Louis selling and installing wood windows, storm sashes, and screen doors.
Becomes a Crawford Door distributor, pivoting to sectional garage door sales and installation.
Incorporates as Zumwalt Corporation. Shifts focus to residential garage doors as aluminum renders storm door manufacturing uncompetitive.
Maurice Richard Zumwalt II ("Dick"), a Washington University-educated Army veteran, joins the company as a salesman.
Acquires Missouri Overhead Door. Receives the International Door Association Heritage Award honoring the company's legacy.
Tripp Zumwalt, third-generation, becomes CEO and president. The company now operates 20 trucks with 32 employees, debt-free.

landmarks.description: One of America's oldest garage door dealers, family-owned since 1924. Three generations of Zumwalts have operated from this 1916 Lafayette Avenue building, providing commercial and residential garage doors, loading dock equipment, and specialty door products across the St. Louis metro area.

landmarks.name: Gausnell, O'Keefe & Thomas
amenities: Licensed in MO, IL, and KS

history.event: Firm relocates to permanent home at 1717 Park Ave, an 1885 former livery stable converted to modern offices.

landmarks.description: Trial-focused civil litigation firm with 12 attorneys who have collectively tried nearly 250 jury trials to verdict. Practice areas include construction law, insurance coverage, product liability, medical malpractice, and transportation.

landmarks.name: Edward Jones
landmarks.description: Financial advisor Ryan Ederle provides personalized investment management, retirement planning, and insurance services from his Lafayette Square office.

landmarks.name: Modern Dollar Planning

history.event: Modern Dollar Planning founded.
Mark Schweiss acquires the firm and relocates to Lafayette Square, bringing 25+ years of advisory experience.

landmarks.description: Fee-only fiduciary financial planning and investment management firm specializing in corporate executives and medical professionals. Led by Mark Schweiss (CFP, CFA, CPA) with $104M in client assets under management.

landmarks.name: McAvoy Realty

history.event: Mike and Carolyn McAvoy found the brokerage in Lafayette Square.
Fritz McAvoy takes over as second-generation owner, continuing the family legacy of neighborhood real estate expertise.

landmarks.description: Multi-generational, family-owned real estate brokerage with 40+ years in Lafayette Square. Specializes in residential buying and selling throughout the St. Louis metro, with deep expertise in historic south city properties.

landmarks.name: Rome West Realty

history.event: Susan Sauer founds Rome West Realty, named for the architectural and cultural parallels between St. Louis and Rome.

landmarks.description: Full-service real estate brokerage providing commercial and residential sales and leasing across the St. Louis region. Founded by Susan Sauer with 16+ years of market experience.

landmarks.name: Incite Design Studio
amenities: Four offices: KC, Overland Park, STL, Wichita

history.event: Incite Design Studio founded to provide client-focused architectural design, initially specializing in K-12 education facilities.

landmarks.description: Multi-office architectural design firm with 31 professionals including 14 licensed architects. Specializes in K-12 educational facilities, commercial buildings, and government projects. St. Louis studio led by Michelle Muir.

landmarks.name: Kuhl Swaine

history.event: Dave Swaine and David Kuhl found the agency in Lafayette Square after leaving Arnold Worldwide. Swaine previously co-created the legendary Budweiser Frogs campaign (Super Bowl XXIX, 1995).
Agency grows to 14 employees operating from a three-story brownstone. Clients include Bass Pro Shops, Stifel Financial, and the St. Louis Blues.

landmarks.description: Independent full-service advertising agency founded by Budweiser Frogs co-creator Dave Swaine. Known for bold, category-disrupting campaigns for clients including Bass Pro Shops, Stifel Financial, St. Louis Blues, and Klipsch.

landmarks.name: Have A Cow
amenities: Farm-to-table from own Hereford cattle ranch
Urban farm store with beef, honey, eggs

history.event: Steve St. Pierre purchases a 180-acre farm in Owensville, MO and buys 12 cows — with zero farming experience — inspired by a conversation about creating employment opportunities.
Have A Cow opens January 20 at 2742 Lafayette Ave, bridging rural and urban communities while providing jobs for underemployed residents.

landmarks.description: Ranch-themed cafe and urban farm store serving farm-to-table breakfast, brunch, and lunch with flame-broiled burgers from owner Steve St. Pierre's own Hereford cattle ranch near Cuba, Missouri.

landmarks.name: Prohibition
amenities: Craft cocktails by NYC-trained beverage director

history.event: Centennial Malt House built as part of a brewery complex. During actual Prohibition, the building pivoted to producing ice.
Cally and Rich Conyers open Prohibition on October 24 in the restored basement, with beverage director Benjamin Bauer (ex-NYC) and consulting from Tim Wiggins (Extra Wavy, upstairs).

landmarks.description: 1920s speakeasy-inspired cocktail bar in the stone-walled basement of the 1876 Centennial Malt House. No sign marks the entrance — guests discover it themselves. Dedicated to the remarkable women of the Prohibition era.

landmarks.name: J. Arthurs Salon
landmarks.description: Full-service diverse hair and beauty salon offering hair care, nail services, waxing, skin care, makeup, and massages in historic Lafayette Square.

landmarks.name: Salon One Six One

history.event: Charlie Kirk-Martin founds Salon One Six One with just 2 stylists, naming it after the golden ratio (1.61) — timeless balance found in nature, architecture, and art.

landmarks.description: Aveda concept salon named after the golden ratio (1.61), dedicated to balanced, timeless beauty with eco-friendly products. Founded by Charlie Kirk-Martin with a philosophy of stylist autonomy and continued education.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Square Chiropractic Centre

history.event: Dr. Crystal Peairs founds Lafayette Square Chiropractic Centre after her own recovery from a debilitating car accident at age 21 inspired her chiropractic career.

landmarks.description: Family-focused chiropractic wellness practice led by Dr. Crystal Peairs with 3 chiropractors on staff. Ranked Top 20 chiropractors in St. Louis. Specializes in spinal adjustments, sports injury, and prenatal care.

landmarks.name: Associated Counseling & Assessment

history.event: Practice established, providing certified assessments and professional treatment services. All programs certified by the Missouri Division of Behavioral Health.

landmarks.description: Mental health counseling and assessment practice providing individual counseling, substance abuse treatment, SATOP, anger management, and court-approved behavioral programs from its Lafayette Square satellite office.

landmarks.name: Four Muddy Paws
amenities: Retailer of the Year 2023/2024 (Pet Product News)

history.event: Founded by Matt Brazelton and Jeff Jensen as a natural pet food market.
Moves to Lafayette Square location at 1711 Park Ave.
Transitions to new ownership under Stephanie and Jesse Windsor. Stephanie started as a sales associate 8+ years earlier.

landmarks.description: Natural pet food market and neighborhood hub for dogs and cats, offering self-service dog wash, professional grooming, all-natural food, freshly baked treats, and curated supplies. LGBTQIA+-owned, Retailer of the Year 2023/2024.

landmarks.name: CBD Kratom

history.event: David Palatnik and Dafna Revah open the first dedicated CBD Kratom store in Chicago's Bucktown — the first shop of its kind in the country.

landmarks.description: CBD, kratom, and cannabis dispensary with over 300 products including edibles, beverages, topicals, and smokables. Part of the largest privately owned cannabis and kratom retailer in the US with 55+ locations.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Square Restoration Committee

history.event: Founded by homeowners determined to restore the once-grand Victorian homes that had fallen into 70 years of decline after the devastating 1896 tornado.
Their efforts lead to Lafayette Square being designated St. Louis's first historic district by city ordinance and listed on the National Register of Historic Places.

landmarks.description: 501(c)(3) neighborhood preservation nonprofit founded in 1969, headquartered in the 1867 Park House (a former police station). Facilitates preservation and redevelopment of the Lafayette Square historic district.

landmarks.name: Barr Branch Library

history.event: Andrew Carnegie gifts funds for a Central Library and six branches. Land donated by William Barr, Scottish-born merchant.
Barr Branch completed in Classical Revival style, designed by Theodore C. Link (architect of Union Station). First of six Carnegie-funded branches in St. Louis.
Creative Experience makerspace launches, offering 3D printing, laser cutting, audio/video production, and VR — all free to the public.

landmarks.description: Historic 1906 Carnegie library designed by Theodore C. Link (architect of Union Station). Houses the Creative Experience makerspace with 3D printing, laser cutting, audio/video studios, and VR — all free to the public.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Park Conservancy

history.event: Lafayette Park established by city ordinance — 30 acres reserved when the St. Louis Common was divided in 1836.
Lafayette Park Conservancy founded on the 150th anniversary of the park's creation, dedicated to restoring its historic legacy.

landmarks.description: 501(c)(3) nonprofit preserving Lafayette Park — the oldest developed urban park west of the Mississippi, established 1851. Major projects include restoring the ornamental iron fence and returning the 1876 Music Stand to its Victorian appearance.

landmarks.name: Climb So iLL
amenities: 30,000+ sq ft of climbing terrain (bouldering, top rope, lead)
Full weight and cardio fitness area

history.event: Brothers David and Daniel Chancellor and friend Ian Anderson open Climb So iLL, expanding their climbing hold company So iLL Holds into a full gym inside the historic Power Plant of the 1905 City Hospital complex.

landmarks.description: World-class indoor climbing gym in the restored Power Plant of the historic City Hospital complex, identifiable by its towering smokestack. Over 30,000 sq ft of bouldering, top rope, and lead climbing terrain for all skill levels.

landmarks.name: Moulin Events & Meetings
amenities: Eight private event spaces (20 to 750 guests)
Rooftop deck with Arch and downtown skyline views
Arcade game room with pinball, skee ball, and jukebox

history.event: Centennial Malt House built by Joseph Schnaider as the mill for his Chouteau Avenue Brewery — one of St. Louis's top three breweries. 'Moulin' is French for mill, honoring this origin.
After a $4 million restoration by Wendy and Paul Hamilton, Moulin Events hosts its first event on April 29. Named to Landmarks Association's Eleven Most Enhanced Places.

landmarks.description: Full-service event venue occupying eight private spaces across the restored 1876 Centennial Malt House, with exposed brick, arched windows, soaring ceilings, and views of the Gateway Arch.

landmarks.name: Comfort Inn & Suites Lafayette Square

history.event: Built and opened as Hotel Avyan, a 64-room hotel on Lafayette Avenue. Later rebranded as a Comfort Inn & Suites franchise under Choice Hotels.

landmarks.description: A 64-room Comfort Inn franchise two blocks from Lafayette Park, offering complimentary breakfast, free parking, and pet-friendly accommodations. Formerly Hotel Avyan, convenient to downtown St. Louis and the Gateway Arch.

landmarks.name: The Dreamer's Loft
amenities: Content creation studio with photo-ready backdrops and ring lights
Three designer Zoom rooms for video calls
Wellness room with zero gravity massage chair
Event space for workshops, pop-ups, and private gatherings

history.event: Jody Cox, founder of Dream by Design STL and veteran event designer of 15 years, opens The Dreamer's Loft as St. Louis's first creative coworking and content creation studio in the iconic pink building at 2710 Lafayette Avenue.

landmarks.description: St. Louis's first creative coworking and content creation studio, housed in a striking pink building on Lafayette Avenue. Offers dedicated desks, meeting rooms, photo-ready studios, and event rentals for creatives and entrepreneurs.

landmarks.name: Walgreens
landmarks.description: Full-service Walgreens drugstore and pharmacy at the corner of Lafayette Ave and S. Jefferson Ave, serving the neighborhood with prescriptions, health services, and everyday essentials.

landmarks.name: Lofts at Lafayette Square
amenities: 14-foot ceilings and open loft floor plans

history.event: Roberts, Johnson & Rand — then the largest shoe manufacturer in the U.S. — operates its factory at this site during Lafayette Square's industrial heyday.
The 148,000 sq ft shoe plant is converted into 115 loft apartments with soaring ceilings and industrial character preserved.

landmarks.description: 115-unit loft apartment community in the converted Roberts, Johnson & Rand shoe factory, featuring 14-foot ceilings, open floor plans, and historic industrial character in the heart of Lafayette Square.

landmarks.name: Wireworks Lofts

history.event: The historic Western Wire Products factory is converted into 79 market-rate loft apartments and 8,000 sq ft of ground-floor retail and office space, financed with historic preservation tax credits.

landmarks.description: 79-unit loft community in the converted Western Wire Products factory, featuring high ceilings, large windows, and ground-floor retail anchored by SqWires Restaurant.

landmarks.name: 2200 LaSalle at Lafayette Square
amenities: Clubhouse with cocktail bar and fitness center
Courtyard with fire pit, pavilion, and lawn games

history.event: 128-unit, five-story luxury apartment complex opens on the former Praxair industrial site — phase one of a 12-acre master-planned redevelopment at Jefferson and Chouteau. Designed by HOK, built by IMPACT Strategies.

landmarks.description: 128-unit luxury apartment complex with resort-style amenities on the former Praxair site. Studio, one-, and two-bedroom units with premium finishes, quartz countertops, and open-concept design.

landmarks.name: Family Dollar
landmarks.description: National discount retail chain offering household essentials, cleaning supplies, food and beverages, health and beauty products, and seasonal items at everyday low prices.

landmarks.name: Fit City STL

history.event: Fit City STL opens at 1601 S Jefferson Avenue in the Jefferson Commons plaza, offering a full-service gym with extensive free weight and cardio equipment.

landmarks.description: Full-service gym in the Jefferson Commons plaza with one of the largest and most diverse equipment selections in St. Louis. Features 55+ cardio pieces, 43+ plate-loaded machines, tanning, saunas, personal training, childcare, and a smoothie bar. Also operates a second location in St. Peters.

landmarks.name: H&R Block
landmarks.description: National tax preparation franchise offering in-person and virtual tax filing services. Located in Suite B of the Jefferson Commons plaza near Lafayette Square.

landmarks.name: RE/MAX Gold
amenities: Part of the #1 RE/MAX franchise worldwide

history.event: RE/MAX Gold office opens at 1900 Park Avenue in Lafayette Square, growing into one of the top-producing RE/MAX franchises in the country.

landmarks.description: Real estate brokerage office on Park Avenue in the heart of Lafayette Square. Part of the Gold Nation network — the #1 RE/MAX franchise in the world — with multiple licensed agents serving the St. Louis metro area in residential and commercial real estate.

landmarks.name: Care Solutions In-Home Services
amenities: Free CPR classes and safety equipment
landmarks.description: Private, nurse-owned and family-operated home care agency providing customized supportive services including personal care, medication management, meal preparation, and errands. Serves private pay clients as well as Medicaid In-Home Services and Veterans benefit programs across St. Louis and surrounding counties. Neighborhood Favorite on Nextdoor in 2023.

landmarks.name: Onyx Dagger Tattoo & Gallery
amenities: Rotating fine art gallery featuring local and national artists
Custom tattoo design by appointment only
Art available for purchase on site

history.event: Valencia Miller, known as 'Miss V,' founds Onyx Dagger Tattoo, becoming the first Black woman in Missouri to own and operate a custom tattoo shop.
Onyx Dagger reopens at 1917 Park Avenue in Lafayette Square as a combined tattoo studio and fine art gallery, featuring rotating exhibitions alongside custom tattoo work.

landmarks.description: Female-owned custom tattoo studio and fine art gallery in the heart of Lafayette Square. Owner Valencia Miller, the first Black woman in Missouri to own a custom tattoo shop, combines over 16 years of tattooing expertise with a curated gallery showcasing local and nationally renowned artists.

landmarks.name: Lehmann House Bed & Breakfast
amenities: Free Wi-Fi and free off-street parking
Guest library with baby grand piano in the parlor
Five individually decorated rooms with private baths and fireplaces

history.event: Financier Edward S. Rowse builds the grand 26-room mansion at 10 Benton Place, St. Louis's oldest private street.
Frederick and Nora Lehmann purchase the mansion. As U.S. Solicitor General and director of the 1904 World's Fair, Lehmann hosts three sitting presidents in the home.
After two years of renovation, the mansion opens as the Lehmann House Bed & Breakfast — now the longest-running B&B in the St. Louis area.

landmarks.description: Historic 1893 Victorian mansion on Benton Place, St. Louis's oldest private street, operating as the city's longest-running bed and breakfast. Five individually appointed guest rooms with period antiques, private baths, and fireplaces.

landmarks.name: Wildflowers STL
amenities: Daily fresh arrangements and sympathy flowers

history.event: Wildflowers founded by Jane Winter in Webster Groves. Relocated in 2001 to St. Louis's historic Floral Row near LaSalle Street. Sara purchased the studio in 2016, earning eight Knot Best of Weddings awards.

landmarks.description: A premier artisan florist with nearly 30 years in business, tucked behind Lafayette Avenue on historic Floral Row. Owner Sara crafts whimsical, garden-style arrangements with blooms sourced daily from local farms and around the world.

landmarks.name: Rescued Furnishings
amenities: DIY furniture painting and building classes
Custom vintage and antique furniture restoration
Cabinet painting and kitchen remodel services
Curated home decor and gift shop

history.event: Nicole and Brandt Genz, both engineers, turn their garage furniture-flipping hobby into Rescued Furnishings. Nicole leaves her Boeing career in 2014 to run it full-time.

landmarks.description: A husband-and-wife furniture studio specializing in one-of-a-kind vintage and antique pieces restored with custom paint, stain, and carpentry. The Lafayette Square showroom doubles as a home-decor gift shop and DIY workshop.

landmarks.name: Sognare on Lafayette
amenities: Flexible floor plan for up to 150 seated guests
In-house floral and decor styling via An Affair to Remember and Styled & Staged

history.event: Sognare on Lafayette opens inside the pink DREAM building at 2714 Lafayette Avenue, created by the woman-owned Dream by Design team. 'Sognare' is Italian for 'to dream.'

landmarks.description: A chic, contemporary event space inside Lafayette Square's iconic pink DREAM building, designed by award-winning event planners. Lush overhead greenery, bistro lighting, hanging rattan chandeliers, and white-washed brick walls accommodate weddings and celebrations for up to 150 guests.

landmarks.name: Architectural Artifacts of St. Louis
amenities: 36,000 sq ft warehouse and outdoor yards
Salvaged cast iron, terra cotta, stone, and brick

history.event: Bruce Gerrie founds the business as 'After the Paint' at 18th & Hickory in Lafayette Square — the first architectural salvage operation in St. Louis.
Gerrie begins collaborating with artist Bob Cassilly, supplying salvaged materials for the City Museum and curating its St. Louis Architectural Museum gallery.

landmarks.description: The oldest architectural salvage business in St. Louis, founded in 1973 by Bruce Gerrie. A 36,000 sq ft warehouse packed with cast iron storefronts, decorative terra cotta, stained glass, reclaimed lumber, and historic building fragments. Open Thursdays and Saturdays only.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Park Bed and Breakfast
amenities: Walking distance to Lafayette Park and neighborhood restaurants

history.event: Victorian residence constructed on Missouri Avenue facing Lafayette Park during the neighborhood's Gilded Age building boom, later restored and converted into a bed and breakfast by innkeeper Larry Bennett.

landmarks.description: A Victorian bed and breakfast facing Lafayette Park in the heart of the historic district, hosted by innkeeper Larry Bennett. Period-furnished guest rooms with complimentary breakfast and walking access to the neighborhood's best restaurants.

landmarks.name: J3 Studio

history.event: Judith Southard opens J3 Studio in Lafayette Square, establishing a woman-owned boutique spa offering facials, waxing, lash extensions, and makeup services.

landmarks.description: Woman-owned boutique spa in Lafayette Square, open since 2008. Owner and licensed esthetician Judith Southard offers luxurious facials, expert waxing, lash extensions, and makeup application in a calm, welcoming setting. By appointment only.

landmarks.name: Lafayette Square Wellness
amenities: Swim spa for fitness and relaxation

history.event: Lafayette Square Wellness opens at 2327 Hickory Street, bringing infrared sauna, swim spa, facials, chemical peels, and aesthetic injection services to the neighborhood.

landmarks.description: Full-service wellness studio on Hickory Street offering infrared sauna sessions, swim spa workouts, spa facials, HydraFacials, chemical peels, and aesthetic treatments including neurotoxin and dermal filler injections.

landmarks.name: Grand Hall on Chouteau
amenities: Over 13,000 sq ft ballroom with 40-foot stage
2,800 sq ft Atrium for cocktail hours and ceremonies

history.event: Sheet Metal Workers Local 36 completes a $29.5 million retrofit of its training complex at Jefferson and Chouteau, earning LEED Platinum certification. The Grand Hall opens as a premier event space within the complex.

landmarks.description: Over 13,000 sq ft event venue inside the LEED Platinum Sheet Metal Workers Local 36 complex, featuring a breathtaking ballroom with soaring ceilings, skylights, and a 40-foot stage accommodating up to 500 seated or 850 standing guests. Orlando's Catering is the exclusive caterer.

landmarks.name: St. Louis Dental Education & Oral Health Center
amenities: 92-chair dental clinic with general and specialty care
Sliding fee scale for uninsured patients
Pediatric dentistry and special needs dental services
Full specialty care: periodontics, endodontics, prosthodontics, oral surgery

history.event: The $24 million, 79,000 sq ft clinic opens June 15 — a partnership between A.T. Still University's Missouri School of Dentistry and Affinia Healthcare, training dental students while serving thousands of underserved St. Louis residents.

landmarks.description: A $24 million, 79,000 sq ft state-of-the-art dental clinic and teaching facility operated by Affinia Healthcare in partnership with A.T. Still University. The 92-chair clinic provides affordable general and specialty dental care to underserved communities while training the next generation of dentists.

landmarks.name: Eden Lofts
amenities: Gateway Arch views from upper units

history.event: Built for the Eden Publishing Company, a major German-language religious publisher. The adjacent five-story Art Deco wing designed by Hoener, Boehm & Froese was added in 1929.
Added to the National Register of Historic Places for architectural and historical significance.
Converted into 40 residential loft condominiums with open floor plans, 12-foot ceilings, and preserved industrial character.

landmarks.description: 40-unit loft condominium building in the converted 1896 Eden Publishing Company headquarters, a National Register-listed Art Deco landmark on Chouteau Avenue. Features 12-foot ceilings, exposed brick, secure gated parking, and Gateway Arch views.
